abstract.text: The object you use to manage data and provide cells for a collection view.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: If you’re working in a Swift codebase, always use

object is a specialized type of data source that works together with your collection view object. It provides the behavior you need to manage updates to your collection view’s data and UI in a simple, efficient way. It also conforms to the
protocol and provides implementations for all of the protocol’s methods.
To fill a collection view with data:
Connect a diffable data source to your collection view.
Implement a cell provider to configure your collection view’s cells.
Generate the current state of the data.
Display the data in the UI.
To connect a diffable data source to a collection view, you create the diffable data source using its

initializer, passing in the collection view you want to associate with that data source. You also pass in a cell provider, where you configure each of your cells to determine how to display your data in the UI.

code: self.dataSource = [[UICollectionViewDiffableDataSource alloc] initWithCollectionView:self.collectionView cellProvider:^UICollectionViewCell *(UICollectionView *collectionView, NSIndexPath *indexPath, id item) {

inlineContent.text: Then, you generate the current state of the data and display the data in the UI by constructing and applying a snapshot. For more information, see

on the collection view after you configure it with a diffable data source. If the collection view needs a new data source after you configure it initially, create and configure a new collection view and diffable data source.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A representation of the state of the data in a layout section at a specific point in time.
A transaction that describes the changes after reordering the items in a section.
A representation of the state of the data in a view at a specific point in time.
A transaction that describes the changes after reordering the items in the view.
The object that provides the data for the collection view.
The methods adopted by the object you use to manage data and provide cells for a collection view.
A protocol that provides advance warning of the data requirements for a collection view, allowing the triggering of asynchronous data load operations.
The object you use to manage data and provide cells for a collection view.
The object you use to manage data and provide cells for a collection view.
Updates the UI to reflect the state of the data in the snapshot, optionally animating the UI changes.
Updates the UI to reflect the state of the data in the snapshot, optionally animating the UI changes and executing a completion handler.
Updates the section UI to reflect the state of the data in the specified snapshot, optionally animating the UI changes.
Updates the section UI to reflect the state of the data in the specified snapshot, optionally animating the UI changes and executing a completion handler.
Resets the UI to reflect the state of the data in the snapshot without computing a diff or animating the changes.
Resets the UI to reflect the state of the data in the snapshot without computing a diff or animating the changes, optionally executing a completion handler.
Returns an index for the section with the identifier you specify in the collection view.
Returns an index path for the item with the specified identifier in the collection view.
Creates a diffable data source with the specified cell provider, and connects it to the specified collection view.
Returns an identifier for the item at the specified index path in the collection view.
The diffable data source’s handlers for reordering items.
Returns an identifier for the section at the index you specify in the collection view.
The diffable data source’s handlers for expanding and collapsing items.
Returns a representation of the current state of the data in the collection view.
Returns a representation of the current state of the data in the specified section of the collection view.
The closure that configures and returns the collection view’s supplementary views, such as headers and footers, from the diffable data source.
A closure that configures and returns a cell for a collection view from its diffable data source.
A closure that configures and returns a collection view’s supplementary view, such as a header or footer, from a diffable data source.
Handlers for reordering items.
Handlers for expanding and collapsing items.
A standard control that can initiate the refreshing of a scroll view’s contents.
Improve the performance of lists and collections in your app with prefetching and image preparation.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Building high-performance lists and collection views

abstract.text: Bring compositional layouts to your app and simplify updating your user interface with diffable data sources.
Streamline the display and update of data in a collection view using a diffable data source that contains identifiers.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Updating collection views using diffable data sources

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
